content:
Dear Sheffield City Council,
Please provide the following information -
- the procedure for students to submit complaints to hold Purpose Built Student Accomodation providers to account under the SNUG scheme?
- the procedure for the council when dealing with such complaints when they have been submitted?
- the number of complaints received by private housing standards regarding Purpose Built Student Accomodation since 2020? Please give a breakdown by provider and reason
Yours faithfully,
Matt Smith

Dear Matt Smith,
Thank you for your request for information relating to Snug scheme
complaints by students which we received on 01/05/2023.
This has been logged as a Freedom of Information Request and will be dealt
with under the Freedom of Information Act 2000. The reference number for
your request can be found above.
The Freedom of Information Act 2000 states that we must respond to you
within 20 working days, by 31/05/2023, but we kindly ask for your patience
as we anticipate that there may be a delay in some cases. Please do not
hesitate to contact us at the email address below if you have any queries.
Yours sincerely,
Sheffield City Council
PO Box 1283
Sheffield, S1 1UJ
Email: [1][Sheffield City Council request email]
From: Matt Smith <[FOI #977092 email]>
Sent: Saturday, April 29, 2023 4:57 PM
To: FOI <[Sheffield City Council request email]>
Subject: Freedom of Information request - SNUG scheme
Dear Sheffield City Council,
Please provide the following information -
- the procedure for students to submit complaints to hold Purpose Built
Student Accomodation providers to account under the SNUG scheme?
- the procedure for the council when dealing with such complaints when
they have been submitted?
- the number of complaints received by private housing standards regarding
Purpose Built Student Accomodation since 2020? Please give a breakdown by
provider and reason
Yours faithfully,
Matt Smith
-------------------------------------------------------------------
Please use this email address for all replies to this request:
[2][FOI #977092 email]
Is [3][Sheffield City Council request email] the wrong address for Freedom of Information
requests to Sheffield City Council? If so, please contact us using this
form:
[4]
https://eur03.safelinks.protection.outlo...
Disclaimer: This message and any reply that you make will be published on
the internet. Our privacy and copyright policies:
[5]
https://eur03.safelinks.protection.outlo...
For more detailed guidance on safely disclosing information, read the
latest advice from the ICO:
[6]
https://eur03.safelinks.protection.outlo...
[7]
https://eur03.safelinks.protection.outlo...
Please note that in some cases publication of requests and responses will
be delayed.
If you find this service useful as an FOI officer, please ask your web
manager to link to us from your organisation's FOI page.
show quoted sections

Dear Matt Smith,
Thank you for your request for information relating to Snug scheme
complaints by students which we received on 01/05/2023.
Please find Sheffield City Council’s response to your request set out
below:
- the procedure for students to submit complaints to hold Purpose Built
Student Accomodation providers to account under the SNUG scheme?
Any occupiers of accommodation that is in the Snug approved accommodation
scheme can complain directly to Private Housing Standards
([1][
email address
] or 0114 2734680) and we will consider those
reports and decide what further action is necessary.  Snug is a scheme
which is run in partnership with both Universities and the Student Unions
so complaints can also be submitted directly to them and they will also
make us aware of the complaint so long as they have the occupier’s
permission to do so.  Anyone that has concerns about student accommodation
not in Snug or any private rented accommodation can contact Private
Housing Standards (PHS) directly as we will address any complaint relating
to property condition and / or management where we have relevant
enforcement powers.
- the procedure for the council when dealing with such complaints when
they have been submitted?
This depends on the type of complaint.  Any complaint submitted to PHS
(Snug related or not) will be received by us and initial advice and
information will be given at the first point of contact.  Where there are
health and safety hazards in the property, the complaint would be
allocated to an officer to investigate; this could include carrying out an
inspection of the property if required.  Where, for example there are
concerns about the behaviour of a landlord or agent, or threats of illegal
eviction, the case would be referred to one of our Tenancy Relations
Officers. We would then work with the landlord / agent to ensure the
complaint is resolved, if this is not possible then we would move to
formal enforcement action should it be necessary.   Where the evidence, on
the balance of probabilities, suggests that the management of the
property, or its condition, falls below the Snug standards, the case will
be referred to our officer panel which meets monthly.  That panel may
decide to warn the member, to suspend them for a limited period pending
further review, or to revoke their membership altogether.
- the number of complaints received by private housing standards regarding
Purpose Built Student Accomodation since 2020? Please give a breakdown by
provider and reason
We do not have a record of the total number of complaints of all kinds
that have been received in relation to all Snug properties.  All
complaints are recorded, considered and dealt with as outlined above but
they are not categorised in such a way as enables us to calculate a total
specifically for Snug properties.   We are able to see how many complaints
have been received in relation to a particular property or landlord and
this informs the action that is taken in relation to a particular landlord
or property, however, not all complaints or reports are proven, and we
cannot provide a breakdown by provider to the public.
Our experience is that we receive significantly fewer complaints about
Snug properties than private rented properties generally, which is as we
would expect given that it is unlikely that landlords with poor properties
and management standards will apply for Snug.  However, despite this we
have still refused Snug membership or revoked the membership of 18
landlords.
If you have any queries about this response, please do not hesitate to
contact us.
The information provided in this response is available for re-use under
the terms of the Open Government Licence v3.0. The terms of the OGL can be
found [2]here. When re-using the information, Sheffield City Council
requires you to include the following attribution statement: “Contains
public sector information obtained from Sheffield City Council and
licensed under the Open Government Licence v3.0.”
If you are unhappy with the response you have received in relation to your
request, you are entitled to have this reviewed. You can ask for an
internal review by replying to this email. Internal review requests should
be submitted within 40 working days from the date of this response.
If you remain dissatisfied with the outcome of your internal review, you
can contact the Information Commissioner’s Office. Please see
[3]
https://ico.org.uk/make-a-complaint/offi...
for further details.
Kind Regards,
Sheffield City Council
PO Box 1283
Sheffield, S1 1UJ
Email: [4][Sheffield City Council request email]
From: Matt Smith <[5][FOI #977092 email]>
Sent: Saturday, April 29, 2023 4:57 PM
To: FOI <[6][Sheffield City Council request email]>
Subject: Freedom of Information request - SNUG scheme
Dear Sheffield City Council,
Please provide the following information -
- the procedure for students to submit complaints to hold Purpose Built
Student Accomodation providers to account under the SNUG scheme?
- the procedure for the council when dealing with such complaints when
they have been submitted?
- the number of complaints received by private housing standards regarding
Purpose Built Student Accomodation since 2020? Please give a breakdown by
provider and reason
Yours faithfully,
Matt Smith
-------------------------------------------------------------------
Please use this email address for all replies to this request:
[7][FOI #977092 email]

requests to Sheffield City Council? If so, please contact us using this
form:

Disclaimer: This message and any reply that you make will be published on
the internet. Our privacy and copyright policies:
[10]
https://eur03.safelinks.protection.outlo...
For more detailed guidance on safely disclosing information, read the
latest advice from the ICO:

Please note that in some cases publication of requests and responses will

If you find this service useful as an FOI officer, please ask your web
manager to link to us from your organisation's FOI page.

Dear FOI,
Please provide the following information:-
- The total number of complaints received for HMOs in the years 2014, 2020, 2021 and 2022
- how many complaints received for each of the years above which were for the following reasons (please give a number for each reason by year):-
- Repairs not being completed.
- Unprofessional behaviour from landlord.
- Other.
Yours sincerely,
Matt Smith

Dear Matt Smith,
Thank you for your request for information relating to HMO complaints
which we received on 21/05/2023.
This has been logged as a Freedom of Information Request and will be dealt
with under the Freedom of Information Act 2000. The reference number for
your request can be found above.
The Freedom of Information Act 2000 states that we must respond to you
within 20 working days, by 20/06/2023, but we kindly ask for your patience
as we anticipate that there may be a delay in some cases. Please do not
hesitate to contact us at the email address below if you have any queries.
Yours sincerely,
Sheffield City Council
PO Box 1283
Sheffield, S1 1UJ

From: Matt Smith <[FOI #977092 email]>
Sent: Sunday, May 21, 2023 10:54 AM
To: FOI <[Sheffield City Council request email]>
Subject: Re: Response – Freedom of Information Request – Reference – FOI /
861068
Dear FOI,
Please provide the following information:-
- The total number of complaints received for HMOs in the years 2014,
2020, 2021 and 2022
- how many complaints received for each of the years above which were for
the following reasons (please give a number for each reason by year):-
- Repairs not being completed.
- Unprofessional behaviour from landlord.
- Other.
Yours sincerely,
Matt Smith

Please note that the Code of Practice does allow us to extend this

Dear Matt Smith
We apologise for providing information for another request to you on 7
June 2023, and for failing to correct this when you drew it to our
attention on 8, 26 and 29 June, and that you have had to complain to the
Information Commissioner. Your request concerned complaints received
connected to Houses in multiple occupation.
We don’t believe we would be able to provide the information you are
asking for under section 12 of the Act. Sheffield City Council does hold
the information you have requested. But our system logs service request
cases under the address, and there isn’t a way for us to filter through
the cases for those years into the categories that you have asked for. We
log all our service requests under the same action code on our system.
There are a few codes that differentiate cases but the majority fall under
the same one or two codes, which is why it would take a manual check per
record to identify if the property is a licenced HMO property, and whether
it would fall under one of the categories in your request.
We estimate that we would need to search 1400 records and that it would
take three minutes to search each record. That would take us 70 hours to
collate the information, which is more than the cost limit of 18 hours or
£450 specified in the [1]Freedom of Information and Data Protection
(Appropriate Limit and Fees) Regulations 2004 (SI 2004 No. 3244).
Under section 16 of the Freedom of Information Act 2000, we have a duty to
provide advice and assistance to requesters. We do not produce reports of
the type you require so specific as to the type of property or issue. If
there’s a need to focus on a certain issue, for example Damp and Mould, we
may report on that, but again we wouldn’t report at the level of a single
family let or an HMO, etc.
Potentially, you could reduce the number of properties to search through,
or you could identify a specific property / properties to look at. Our
register of Houses in Multiple Occupation is here: [2]Apply for a HMO
licence | Sheffield City Council (see Supporting information)
If you have any queries about this response, please do not hesitate to
contact us.
The information provided in this response is available for re-use under
the terms of the Open Government Licence v3.0. The terms of the OGL can be
found [3]here. When re-using the information, Sheffield City Council
requires you to include the following attribution statement: “Contains
public sector information obtained from Sheffield City Council and
licensed under the Open Government Licence v3.0.”
If you are unhappy with the response you have received in relation to your
request, you are entitled to have this reviewed. You can ask for an
internal review by replying to this email. Internal review requests should
be submitted within 40 working days from the date of this response.
If you remain dissatisfied with the outcome of your internal review, you
can contact the Information Commissioner’s Office. Please see
[4]
https://ico.org.uk/make-a-complaint/offi...
for further details.
Kind Regards,
Sheffield City Council
PO Box 1283
Sheffield, S1 1UJ
Email: [5][Sheffield City Council request email]

Dear Sheffield City Council,
Please pass this on to the person who conducts Freedom of Information reviews.
I am writing to request an internal review of Sheffield City Council's handling of my FOI request 'SNUG scheme'.
You have refused to provide the information on cost grounds, but have not made an effort to reach a compromise. Can you please advise what level of information you would be willing to provide in regards to my request which would be within the cost guidelines.
A full history of my FOI request and all correspondence is available on the Internet at this address:
https://www.whatdotheyknow.com/request/s...
Yours faithfully,
Matt Smith

Dear Matt Smith
Thank you for your email requesting a review of Sheffield City Council’s
response to your Freedom of Information request. I can now confirm that a
full and impartial review of the decision made in this case has been
conducted with a summary as follows:
You contacted the council on 21^st May 2023 requesting information
relating to HMO complaints. The response that you received on the 9^th
October 2023 provided an answer to the questions raised, with exemptions
engaged where appropriate. Your email received by the Council on 19^th
October 2023 explained that you were requesting an internal review of your
response.
In relation to the points raised in your request for internal review, I
can confirm that the initial response provided to the FOI request should
be upheld. I have made some further enquiries with key staff at SCC and
determined that as previously advised, the information you have requested
cannot be easily retrieved. Due to the way the data is catalogued, there
is no way to run a report, which depicts property type, and as you are
specifically asking about HMOs, this is not something which we can assist
with.
If you wish to submit a refined request, SCC may be able to provide some
information (within the fees cost limit), if you were to reduce the number
of properties to search, or if you could identify a specific property /
properties on which to focus the search.
Our register of Houses in Multiple Occupation is here: [1]Apply for a HMO
licence | Sheffield City Council (see Supporting information)
If you are dissatisfied with my review, you can make a complaint to the
Information Commissioner’s Office: [2][
email address
]
Kind Regards
Sheffield City Council
Tel: 0114 205 2315
This Email, and any attachments, may contain non-public information and is

contain sensitive or protectively marked material and should be handled

Dear Matt Smith
Thank you for your email requesting a review of Sheffield City Council’s
response to your Freedom of Information request. I can now confirm that a
full and impartial review of the decision made in this case has been
conducted with a summary as follows:
You contacted the Council on 1^st May 2023 requesting information relating
to Snug scheme complaints. The response that you received on the 10^th May
2023 provided an answer to the questions raised, with exemptions engaged
where appropriate. Your email received by the Council on 19^th October
2023 explained that you were requesting an internal review of your
response. We endeavour to provide a response to internal reviews within 20
working days. However, a review can sometimes be delayed and I apologise
for this.
In relation to the points raised in your request for internal review, I
can confirm that the initial response provided to the FOI request should
be upheld. However, the duty to advise and assist was not included within
the response.
I have made some further enquiries with key staff at SCC and determined
that as previously advised, the information you have requested cannot be
easily retrieved. Due to the way the data is catalogued, there is no way
to run a report, which depicts property type, and as you are specifically
asking about Snug properties, this is not something which we can assist
with.
If you wish to submit a refined request, SCC may be able to provide some
information (within the fees cost limit), if you were to reduce the number
of properties to search, or if you could identify a specific property /
properties on which to focus the search.
If you are dissatisfied with my review, you can make a complaint to the
Information Commissioner’s Office: [1][
email address
]
Kind Regards
Sheffield City Council
Tel: 0114 205 2315

Dear Matt Smith
Thank you for your recent request for an internal review relating to
complaints about student properties, which we received on 24/03/2025.
We uphold your complaint regarding the lateness of our response. We
breached Section 10 of the Act by failing to respond within 20 working
days, which was 13 September 2024. We sincerely apologise for our delay.
Please find Sheffield City Council’s response to your request set out
below.
From 1 ^ April 2020 to 8 April 2025, we have received the following number
of complaints about these buildings:-
Leadmill Point – 4
Central Quay – 2
If you have any queries about this response, please do not hesitate to
contact us.
The information provided in this response is available for re-use under
the terms of the Open Government Licence v3.0. The terms of the OGL can be
found [1]here. When re-using the information, Sheffield City Council
requires you to include the following attribution statement: “Contains
public sector information obtained from Sheffield City Council and
licensed under the Open Government Licence v3.0.”
If you are unhappy with the response you have received in relation to your
request, you are entitled to have this reviewed. You can ask for an
internal review by replying to this email. Internal review requests should
be submitted within 40 working days from the date of this response.
If you remain dissatisfied with the outcome of your internal review, you
can contact the Information Commissioner’s Office. Please see
[2]
https://ico.org.uk/make-a-complaint/offi...
for further details.
Kind Regards,
Sheffield City Council
PO Box 1283
